case_name: Son of Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan v. Board of Revenue Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 2108 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2108 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 15, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No. 82 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 15, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No. 82 of 1963.

facts.text: The appellant is the son of Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan, a zamindar of a number of villages in the District of Kheri, Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant son of Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan a zamindar of a number of villages in the District of Kheri, Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant impeached the orders of the Board of Revenue of Uttar Pradesh dated 30 August 1960 and 6 September 1960.

anchor.surface_text: impeached the orders of the Board of Revenue of Uttar Pradesh dated 30 August, 1960 and 6 September, 1960 whereby the Board issued three directions.

facts.text: Board of Revenue issued directions: first to stop payment of instalment money or the bonds by the treasuries.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the Board issued three directions. The first was to stop payment of instalment money or the bonds by the treasuries.

facts.text: Board directed the Compensation Officer to hand over bonds of the face value of Rs. 32,000 remaining with him for liquidation of debts.

anchor.surface_text: The second was to direct the Compensation Officer to hand over bonds of the face value of Rs. 32,000 reported to be remaining with him for liquidation of debts.

facts.text: Board ordered attaching movable and immovable properties belonging to the appellant and his brother for liquidation of debts.

anchor.surface_text: The third was an order attaching movable and immovable properties belonging to the appellant and his brother.for liquidation of debts.

facts.text: Third respondent Raja Shatranjai is the decree-holder and was a creditor of the appellant's father Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan on the basis of a mortgage deed.

anchor.surface_text: The third respondent Raja Shatranjai the decree-holder was a creditor of the appellants father Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan on the basis of a mortgage deed.

facts.text: Raja Shatranjai obtained a decree on the mortgage debt for Rs. 1,31,040-1-0 and Rs. 1931-1-0 as costs, dated 28 September 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Shatranjai obtained a decree on the said mortgage debt for Rs. 1,31,040-1-0 and Rs. 1931-1-0 as companyts. The decree is dated 28 September, 1939.

facts.text: Decree passed under the provisions of the Uttar Pradesh Encumbered Estates Act, 1934 on application of Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan under section 4.

anchor.surface_text: The decree was passed under the provisions of the Uttar Pradesh Encumbered Estates Act, 1934  hereinafter referred to as the1934 Act . The decree was passed on the application of Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan under section 4 of the 1934 Act.

facts.text: Debtor Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan was a zamindar in the District of Lakhimpur Kheri.

anchor.surface_text: The debtor was a zamindar in the District of Lakhimpur Kheri.

facts.text: Decree transferred to the Deputy Commissioner of Kheri for liquidation of debts.

anchor.surface_text: The decree was transferred to the Deputy Commissioner of Kheri for liquidation of debts.

facts.text: U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms. Act, 1951  hereinafter referred to as the 1951 Act  came into, force.

facts.text: Proprietary rights of intermediaries vested in the State Government; intermediaries entitled to receive compensation in lieu thereof.

anchor.surface_text: The proprietary rights of the intermediaries vested in the State Government and the intermediaries were entitled to receiver companypensation in lieu thereof.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor was an intermediary.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor was an intermediary.

facts.text: Appellant on death of father became entitled to 2/3rd of the Zamindari property and compensation therefor.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on the death of his father became entitled to 2/3rd of the Zamindari property and companypensation therefore.

facts.text: Appellant took delivery of compensation bonds of value Rs. 42,750 from Compensation Officer, Lakhimpur.

anchor.surface_text: He took delivery of the companypensation bonds of the value of Rs. 42,750/from the Compensation Officer, Lakhimpur

facts.text: Brother Hikmat Hakim Khan received bonds of value Rs. 21,250.

anchor.surface_text: while bonds of the value of Rs. 21,250 were received by his brother Hikmat Hakim Khan.

facts.text: Total bonds received by appellant and brother: Rs. 64,000.

anchor.surface_text: The total amount of bonds received by the appellant and his brother aggregated Rs. 64,000.

facts.text: On 14 April 1959, decree-holder applied to Collector Kheri for order to return bonds or attach properties to extent of bonds for debt liquidation.

anchor.surface_text: On 14 April, 1959 the decree-holder applied to the Collector, Kheri for an order that the appellant and his brother do return the bonds which they had received from the Compensation Officer failing which their movable and immovable properties to the extent of these bonds be attached for liquidation of their debts.

facts.text: Collector rejected the application on 17 August 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector on 17 August, 1959 rejected the application.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Additional Commissioner, Lucknow on 17 February 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holder preferred an appeal The appeal was dismissed by the Additional Commissioner, Lucknow on. 17 February, 1960.

facts.text: Revision before Board of Revenue allowed on 30 August 1960 by a member.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holder thereupon companymenced revision proceedings before the Board of Revenue. On 30 August, 1960 a member of the Board of Revenue allowed the revision.

facts.text: Another member of Board concurred on 6 September 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On 6 September, 1960 another member of the Board of Revenue companycurred in the order.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court under Article 226 for quashing Board orders.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter made an application to the High Court under Article 226 of the Constitution for an order quashing the order and directions of the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: Single Judge quashed Board order except direction to Compensation Officer for Rs.32,000 bonds.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge quashed the order of the Board of Revenue save and except the direction directing the Compensation Officer to hand over bonds of the face value of Rs. 32,000 reported to be remaining with him for liquidation of debts.

facts.text: Decree-holder preferred appeal to High Court Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the decree--holder preferred an appeal.

facts.text: High Court Bench divided; matter to third Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The Bench of the High Court was divided in their opinion. The matter was placed before the third learned Single Judge.

facts.text: High Court quashed direction No.3 (attachment of properties), upheld other two directions.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court was that direction No. 3 of the Board of Revenue, namely, attachment of movable and immovable properties of the appellant and his brother was quashed. The High Court upheld the other two orders of the Board of Revenue in regard to stoppage of payment of installment money on the bonds by the treasuries and direction on the Compensation Officer to hand over the bonds of the face value of Rs. 32,000 remaining with him for liquidation of the debts.

facts.text: U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 came into force on 26 January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the 1950 Act  came into force on 26 January, 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly upheld the directions of the Board of Revenue. The appeal is therefore dismissed.
Article 226 of the Constitution
This appeal is by certificate from the judgment dated 15th January, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: 23A. Compensation and rehabilitation grant to be placed at the disposal of the Collector --The Collector shall require the Compensation Officer and Rehabilitation Grants Officer as may be necessary to place at his disposal in pursuance of section 70 of the U. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950, the amount of compensation money and rehabilitation grant payable to the landlord in respect of his proprietary rights in land reported to be liable to attachment or sale under the provisions of sub-section (2) of section 19.

concepts.interpretation: Collector requires Compensation Officer to place compensation at disposal for debts liable under s19(2); basis for requisition.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: t recoverable from companypensation and under rehabilitation grant.-- 1  Without prejudice to the provisions of Section 8 of the U. P. Zamindars Debt

concepts.unlisted_description: Placement of compensation at Collector's disposal

anchor.surface_text: 23B. Liquidation of secured debt recoverable from compensation and under rehabilitation grant.-- (1) Without prejudice to the provisions of Section 8 of the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952. the amount or the bonds on account of compensation or rehabilitation grant received by the Collector in pursuance of the requisition under Section 23-A shall be expended or utilised by the Collector in liquidation of the amount of the secured debt which having regard to the provisions of the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 was secured on the proprietary rights in land in respect of which such money has been received.

concepts.interpretation: Collector to utilise compensation/bonds for secured debts first, then other debts in priority; bonds not deliverable to debtor without this.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n the debts, referred to in the said sub-section in order of priority. Both these sections of the 1934 Act refer to section 70 of the 1950 Act. Sectio

concepts.unlisted_description: Liquidation of secured debts from compensation

anchor.surface_text: Section 70 of the said Act is as follows Compensation money to be placed at the disposal of the Court or authority Where before any Court or authority any suit or proceeding is pending which directly or indirectly affects or is likely to affect the right of any person to receive the whole or part of the compensation determined under Chapter III, the Court or authority may require the Compensation Officer to place at its disposal the amount so payable and thereupon the same shall be disposed of in accordance with the orders of such Court or authority.

concepts.interpretation: Court/authority (Collector) can require Compensation Officer to place compensation at disposal for pending proceedings affecting rights.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ilised by the Collector in liquidation of the amount of the secured debt which having regard to the provisions of the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction A

issues.text: whether the first respondent, the Board of Revenue Uttar Pradesh had authority to pass, the order impugned in this appeal

anchor.surface_text: The principal question in this appeal is whether the first respondent, the Board of Revenue Uttar Pradesh had authority to pass, the order impugned in this appeal.

issues.text: whether the appellant could lawfully obtain delivery of the bonds from the Compensation Officer

anchor.surface_text: The question, in the present case, is whether the appellant could lawfully obtain delivery of the bonds from the Compensation Officer. Sections 23A and 23B of the 1934 Act require that the amount or the bonds on account of compensation or rehabilitation grant received by the Collector shall be expended or utilised by the Collector in liquidation of the amount of the secured debt.

issues.text: whether the absence of the service of a requisition confers a right on the judgment-debtor to take away the compensation money or bonds

anchor.surface_text: The absence of the service of a requisition cannot confer a right on the judgment-debtor to take away the compensation money or bonds. The principle is actus curia neminem gravabit.

arguments.claim: Board of Revenue did not have any power to issue the directions

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the Board of Revenue did not have any power to issue the directions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ghtly gave the directions to secure companypliance with the provisions of the statute, and performance of statutory duty by the Collector as well as t

arguments.court_reasoning: Board's directions secure compliance with statutory duties under sections 23A, 23B of 1934 Act and section 70 of 1950 Act

arguments.claim: Special Judge under section 19 of 1934 Act sends decree to Collector for execution per Chapter V and informs of secured debt recoverable from compensation

anchor.surface_text: Under section 19 of the 1934 Act the Special Judge passing the decree is to send the same to the Collector for execution in accordance with the provisions of Chapter V of the 1934 Act.

arguments.claim: Collector shall require Compensation Officer to place compensation at disposal per section 23A of 1934 Act in pursuance of section 70 of 1950 Act for lands liable under section 19(2)

anchor.surface_text: 23A. Compensation and rehabilitation grant to be placed at the disposal of the Collector --The Collector shall require the Compensation Officer and Rehabilitation Grants Officer as may be necessary to place at his disposal in pursuance of section 70 of the U.

arguments.claim: Collector to expend or utilise compensation bonds received per section 23A in liquidation of secured debt per section 23B(1) of 1934 Act, then other debts

Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952. the amount or the bonds on account of compensation or rehabilitation grant received by the Collector

arguments.claim: Section 70 of 1950 Act allows court or authority to require Compensation Officer to place compensation at disposal if proceeding affects right to compensation

anchor.surface_text: Section 70 of the said Act is as follows Compensation money to be placed at the disposal of the Court or authority Where before any Court or authority any suit or proceeding is pending which directly or indirectly affects or is likely to affect the right of any person to receive the whole or part of the compensation determined under Chapter III,

arguments.claim: Notice under rule 77(1) of 1952 Rules does not confer right on intermediary to take bonds due to section 18 proviso of 1934 Act allowing recovery from compensation

anchor.surface_text: The Compensation Officer under rule 77 (1) of the Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Rules, 1952 could issue notice to the intermediary directing him to take delivery of the bonds. The issue of a notice would not clothe the intermediary with the right to take away the bonds because under section 18 of the 1934 Act

arguments.claim: Appellant could not lawfully obtain delivery of the bonds from Compensation Officer

anchor.surface_text: The question, in the present case, is whether the appellant could lawfully obtain delivery of the bonds from the Compensation Officer. Sections 23A and 23B of the 1934 Act require that the amount or the bonds on account of compensation or rehabilitation grant received by the Collector shall be expended or utilised by the Collector

arguments.claim: Absence of service of requisition does not confer right on judgment-debtor to take compensation bonds; actus curia neminem gravabit

anchor.surface_text: The absence of the service of a requisition cannot confer a right on the judgment-debtor to take away the compensation money or bonds. The principle is actus curia neminem gravabit.

arguments.claim: Decree-holder entitled to payment out of compensation grant in satisfaction of decree

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holder under the provisions of the relevant statutes was entitled to be paid out of the compensation grant monies in satisfaction of the decree.

arguments.claim: Board of Revenue rightly directed stoppage of payments and handover of bonds to secure compliance with statute and statutory duty

anchor.surface_text: If the Collector had required the Compensation Officer under section 23A of the 1934 Act to place at his disposal pursuant to section 70 of the 1950 Act the compensation money, the bonds could not have been taken delivery of by the appellant. The Board of Revenue rightly gave the directions to secure compliance with the provisions of the statute,

arguments.claim: Appellants not entitled to receive bonds without satisfying decree; cannot take advantage of own wrong

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were not entitled to, receive the bonds without satisfying the decree. The appellants were wrong in doing so. The appellant could not take advantage of his own wrong.

arguments.claim: Board of Revenue has jurisdiction over performance of statutory obligations by Collector and Compensation Officer

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction and authority of the Board of Revenue in the present appeal touched directly on the performance of statutory obligations by statutory authorities.

arguments.claim: Compensation bonds required by statute to go to Collector for liquidation of secured debts; judgment debtor not entitled without liquidation

anchor.surface_text: The compensation bonds are required by the statute to go to the Collector for liquidation of secured debts. The judgment debtor is not entitled to the compensation bonds without liquidation of the debts in accordance with the provisions of the statute.

holdings.text: The Board of Revenue had authority to pass the impugned orders and directions.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue rightly gave the directions to secure compliance with the provisions of the statute, and performance of statutory duty by the Collector as well as the Compensation Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board's directions enforce statutory obligations under sections 23A and 23B of 1934 Act and section 70 of 1950 Act for Collector and Compensation Officer to handle compensation for debt liquidation.

holdings.text: The appellant could not lawfully obtain delivery of the compensation bonds from the Compensation Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The question, in the present case, is whether the appellant could lawfully obtain delivery of the bonds from the Compensation Officer. Sections 23A and 23B of the 1934 Act require that the amount or the bonds on account of compensation or rehabilitation grant received by the Collector shall be expended or utilised by the Collector in liquidation of the amount of the secured debt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 23A and 23B mandate Collector to receive and utilise bonds for secured debt liquidation; delivery to debtor bypasses this.

holdings.text: Absence of service of requisition does not confer right on judgment-debtor to take compensation bonds.

anchor.surface_text: The absence of the service of a requisition cannot confer a right on the judgment-debtor to take away the compensation money or bonds. The principle is actus curia neminem gravabit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Actus curia neminem gravabit prevents debtor benefiting from administrative delay; statutory scheme prioritises debt liquidation.

holdings.text: Decree-holder entitled to payment out of compensation grant in satisfaction of decree.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holder under the provisions of the relevant statutes was entitled to be paid out of the compensation grant monies in satisfaction of the decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of 1934 Act (ss 18 proviso, 23A, 23B) and 1950 Act s70 allow recovery from compensation as if security persists.

holdings.text: Appellants not entitled to receive bonds without satisfying the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were not entitled to, receive the bonds without satisfying the decree. The appellants were wrong in doing so. The appellant could not take advantage of his own wrong.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory duty requires prior liquidation; debtor cannot benefit from non-compliance or own actions.

holdings.text: Compensation bonds required by statute to go to Collector for liquidation of secured debts; judgment debtor not entitled without liquidation.

anchor.surface_text: The compensation bonds are required by the statute to go to the Collector for liquidation of secured debts. The judgment debtor is not entitled to the compensation bonds without liquidation of the debts in accordance with the provisions of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of ss 23A, 23B 1934 Act and s70 1950 Act mandates Collector utilisation before debtor receipt.

holdings.text: High Court rightly upheld the directions of the Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly upheld the directions of the Board of Revenue. The appeal is therefore dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directions align with statutory scheme for compensation handling and debt recovery.

anchor.surface_text: The question, in the present case, is whether the appellant could lawfully obtain delivery of the bonds from the Compensation Officer. Sections 23A and 23B of the 1934 Act require that the amount or the bonds on account of compensation or rehabilitation grant received by the Collector shall be expended or utilised by the Collector in liquidation of the amount of the secured debt.
The High Court rightly upheld the directions of the Board of Revenue. The appeal is therefore dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly states that absence of service of requisition does not confer right on judgment-debtor, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: The absence of the service of a requisition cannot confer a right on the judgment-debtor to take away the compensation money or bonds. The principle is actus curia neminem gravabit.
The High Court rightly upheld the directions of the Board of Revenue. The appeal is therefore dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were not entitled to, receive the bonds without satisfying the decree. The appellants were wrong in doing so. The appellant could not take advantage of his own wrong.
